metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof High-Risk Airway Management in the Emergency Department: Diseases and Approaches Part I Title: High-Risk Airway Management in the Emergency Department: Diseases and Approaches Part I

abstract.text: Background: Successful airway management is critical to the practice of emergency medicine. 5

Thus, emergency physicians must be ready to optimize and prepare for airway management in 6 critically ill patients with a wide range of physiologic challenges. Challenges in airway 7 management commonly encountered in the emergency department are discussed using a pearl 8 and pitfall discussion in this first part of a two-part series. 9

Objective: This narrative review presents an evidence-based approach to airway and patient 10 management during endotracheal intubation in challenging cases commonly encountered in the 11 emergency department. 12 Discussion: Adverse events during emergent airway management are common with post-13 intubation cardiac arrest reported in as many as 1 in 25 intubations. Many of these adverse events 14 can be avoided by proper identification and understanding the underlying physiology, 15 preparation, and post intubation management. Those with high risk features including severe 16 metabolic acidosis; shock and hypotension; obstructive lung disease; pulmonary hypertension, 17 right ventricle failure, and pulmonary embolism; and severe hypoxemia must be managed with 18 airway expertise. 19
Conclusions: This narrative review discusses the pearls and pitfalls of commonly encountered 20 physiologic high-risk intubations with a focus on the emergency clinician. 21
Keywords: airway; post-intubation cardiac arrest; metabolic acidosis; shock; hypotension; 22 hypoxemia; obstructive lung disease; pulmonary hypertension; pulmonary embolism 23

body_text.text: Successful airway management is a critical skill in emergency medicine. 1, 2 The majority of 26 emergent and unplanned intubations in emergency departments (ED) are managed by emergency 27 physicians using rapid-sequence intubation, with success rates as high as 99%. 2-4 However, 28 emergency physicians must be able to prepare for and manage critically ill patients with a wide 29 range of physiologic challenges in the peri-intubation setting. 30 31 First pass success is a priority in any attempt at endotracheal intubation, but especially in 32 physiologically challenging airways, as multiple attempts are associated with an increase in 33 adverse events. 5,6 Difficult visualization and intubation, generally defined as 3 or more attempts, 34 occur as often as 6.6-12% in critically ill patients. [6] [7] [8] [9] This rate may be decreasing in the ED 35 population, potentially because of video laryngoscopy or improved techniques, as shown by a 36 decreased rate of multiple attempts of 1.5% in a more recent study of ED intubations. 4 Severe 37 complications occur as frequently as 24-28% of endotracheal intubation in critically ill patients, 38 most commonly hypoxemia and hypotension. 6, 8 Patients with high risk comorbid disease and 39

pre-intubation factors such as hypoxemia, hypotension, and severe acidosis are at high risk for 40 peri-intubation hemodynamic collapse and resultant worse outcomes. 8,10-13 The incidence of 41 peri-intubation cardiac arrest is as high as 1 in 25 emergency airways in one series. 10 Post-42 intubation hypotension is more common, occurring as frequently as 25% of emergency 43 intubations and is associated with increased mortality. 11 Many of the pre-intubation risks for 44 decompensation can be recognized and prevented with proper preparation and evaluation. 8,10,14-18 45 46 This first part of a two-part series will focus on the latest literature, recommendations, and 47 tidal volume of 8 mL/kg predicted body weight (PBW) or higher may be needed. A blood gas 120 should be assessed within 15 minutes of intubation to make sure the pH has not significantly 121 worsened. Continuous ETCO 2 may be used to follow PaCO 2 once intubated; in the patient with 122 normal lung function the ETCO 2 value is 2-5 mm Hg lower than PaCO 2 . 20,31 123 124 There are many different mechanical ventilator strategies post intubation. 12,24 When the sedation 125 and neuromuscular blockade medications are metabolized some advocate for spontaneous 126 ventilatory modes such as pressure support ventilation so the patient can set the respiratory rate, 127 tidal volume, and inspiratory time. 12 Alternatively, adequate sedation and assist control modes of 128 ventilation with a prescribed tidal volume (e.g. VC-AC) or pressure (PC-AC) and respiratory rate 129 may be used, but the patient should be monitored for patient-ventilator dyssynchrony with the 130 increased respiratory drive stimulated by the acidosis. 12,24 The recommended approach is to 131 deliver a guaranteed minute ventilation by setting the respiratory rate and a starting tidal volume 132 of 8 mL/kg PBW in an assist control type mode.

Patients with shock and hypotension requiring intubation and mechanical ventilation are at high 144 risk for peri-intubation cardiovascular collapse. 7,8,10,17,32 Post intubation hypotension (PIH) is 145 common and occurs in up to 25% of emergently intubated patients, is associated with adverse 146 outcomes, and should be aggressively avoided and treated. 8,11,12,33 Studies suggest pre-intubation 147 hypotension and shock index >0.8-0.9 (heart rate/systolic blood pressure [BP] ) are the best 148 predictors of post-intubation cardiac arrest and PIH. 7,10,12,17,32 The shock index is associated with 149 severity of illness and suggests impending instability. 17 Post-intubation cardiac arrest occurs in 150 approximately 2%, though one series reported a higher rate of 4.2% in emergency intubations. 10 151

The reported incidence of cardiac arrest in those with pre-intubation hypotension is even higher 152 at 12-15% of emergency intubations. 7,10 Post intubation cardiac arrest is unsurprisingly 153 associated with increased mortality. 8
In those with anticipated hemodynamic instability, the dosing and familiarity of the induction
body_text.section: Pitfall: Using induction agents or inappropriate doses that worsen or precipitate hypotension. 190

body_text.text: Respiratory failure from obstructive lung disease, such as asthma and chronic obstructive 214 and a respiratory acidosis with a pH of > 7.20 can be tolerated in most patients aside from those 264 with a potential contraindication to a respiratory acidosis such as those with pulmonary 265 hypertension, brain injuries at risk for increased intracranial pressure (ICP), severe right sided 266 heart failure, pregnancy, and certain toxic ingestions. 49 267 Table 3 obstructive lung disease likely indicates hyperinflation from auto-PEEP. 53 The peak pressure will be elevated due to airway resistance, but this pressure is less important, and can be tolerated, if 282 the plateau pressure remains < 30 cm H 2 O, since the peak pressure is not transmitted to the 283 alveoli of lung parenchyma. 24,28,53 An example of a pressure waveform in a mechanically 284 ventilated patient with high airway resistance is demonstrated in Figure 2 . requiring emergent intubation in the ICU, preoxygenation with NIPPV compared to non-408 rebreather mask resulted in an increased SpO 2 after preoxygenation as well as during and after 409 intubation. 67 Episodes of severe desaturation to SpO 2 < 80% were significantly less common in 410 the NIPPV group than the control group (2/27 compared to 12/26). 67 The FLORALI-2 trial 411 compared preoxygenation with HFNC to NIPPV in 322 ICU patients with acute hypoxemic 412 respiratory failure. 68 It found no significant difference in the incidence of severe hypoxemia or 413 serious adverse events between groups. However, in the subgroup of patients with pre-intubation 414 moderate-to-severe hypoxemia (Pa0 2 /FiO 2 < 200), NIPPV resulted in a statistically significant 415 decrease in incidence of severe hypoxemia. 68 Of note, the lack of difference may be confounded 416 by the fact that NIPPV ventilation group received no apneic oxygenation while the HFNC group 417 continued to receive apneic oxygenation via HFNC. NIPPV may be beneficial in those with 418 severe hypoxemia for preoxygenation, as this group had equivalent overall outcomes and 419 reduced hypoxemia despite not receiving apneic oxygenation. 68 The benefit of HFNC for preoxygenation and apneic oxygenation compared to conventional 428 oxygen therapy is unclear. Several small randomized controlled trials comparing HFNC to BVM 429 or face mask in hypoxemic patients found no statistically significant difference in mean lowest 430
body_text.section: Pitfall: Failure to aggressively treat with NIPPV prior to intubation. 213

body_text.text: SpO 2 between groups. [70] [71] [72] Recently, the OPTINIV trial compared the combination of HFNC 431 and NIPPV to NIPPV alone for preoxygenation in ICU patients requiring intubation for 432 hypoxemic respiratory failure. 73 The intervention group (HFNC + NIPPV) continued to receive 433 apneic oxygenation via HFNC while the NIPPV group alone received no further oxygenation 434 after the standardized 4-minute preoxygenation period. Authors found that the intervention 435 groups had higher minimum SpO 2 during intubation (100% vs 96%) and fewer episodes of 436 desaturation SpO 2 <80% (0% vs 21%) than the control group. 73 It is important to note that these preoxygenation strategies are effective in those requiring 443 intubation due to respiratory infections. In the study by Baillard et al, 65-70% of included 444 patients had a diagnosis of pneumonia. 67 Additionally, 35% of study participants in the 445 FLORALI-2 trial had primary respiratory failure due to infection. 68 Though discussion of airway 446 management for patients with novel COVID-19 is beyond the scope of this paper, in the midst of 447 a respiratory illness pandemic appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) with airborne 448 precautions, careful donning and doffing of PPE, and use of negative pressure rooms should be 449 employed to reduce the risk of disease transmission. If a negative pressure room is not available, 450 a private room with a closed door is recommended. If COVID-19 is suspected, video 451 laryngoscopy is recommended. Viral filters must also be appropriately utilized. Emergency clinicians are experts in airway management and routinely encounter critically ill 457 patients with pre-and post-intubation physiologic challenges associated with adverse events.
body_text.section: Pearl: Use an initial ventilator strategy as shown in

body_text.text: Those with a severe metabolic acidosis require maintenance of the minute ventilation to prevent 459 a sudden deterioration in pH. In the case of shock and hypotension, resuscitation prior to 460 induction is the goal, and a shock index of >0.8-0.9 predicts post intubation hypotension. 461
body_text.section: Pearl: Preoxygenate using NIPPV in a head-elevated position if the patient's clinical

body_text.text: Preceding hypoxemia should be aggressively preoxygenated using NIPPV. Pulmonary 462 hypertension and right ventricle failure present complex physiologic challenges; the major goal 463 is to avoid systemic hypotension or a sudden increase in PVR from hypercapnia or hypoxemia. 464
body_text.section: Pearl: Preoxygenate using NIPPV in a head-elevated position if the patient's clinical

body_text.text: Obstructive lung disease presents a risk of hemodynamic collapse from high intrathoracic 465 pressure caused by air-trapping, and patients require prolonged expiratory times with slow 466 respiratory rate while mechanically ventilated. These considerations can assist emergency 467 clinicians in optimizing the patient during and after intubation attempts. 468 469 470 Table 1 . Pearls and pitfalls in the management of high-risk airways.

FIGREF0.text: 133 Pearl: Match at least the pre-intubation respiratory rate, to approximate minute ventilation, to 134 the post-intubation respiratory rate while monitoring for air-trapping. Most patients tolerate a 135 respiratory rate up to 30 breaths per minute. A blood gas should be assessed shortly after 136 intubation to ensure the pH has not decreased. 137 Air-trapping on pressure waveform. 139 140

FIGREF1.text: 191 agent are likely more important than the agent itself. Any induction agent may cause hypotension 192 by blunting the sympathetic response. 42,43 The risk of awareness during neuromuscular blockade 193 should be considered, but a dose reduction of the induction agent by at least 50% in unstable 194 patients is recommended to prevent the deleterious consequences of worsening hemodynamic 195 compromise. 17,43,44 Incremental, low doses of an induction agent until desired level of sedation 196 prior to neuromuscular blockade is another option. 24 Propofol has the highest rate of hypotension 197 by causing myocardial depression, vasodilation, and suppression of the sympathetic drive. 35,45 198 Etomidate is regarded as hemodynamically neutral and remains a common and reliable option in 199 unstable patients. 8,17,45 Ketamine has been used safely in patients with shock and is regarded as 200 having favorable hemodynamic effects and avoids the possible risk of reversible adrenal 201 suppression associated with etomidate. 25,41,46,47 Ketamine acts as a sympathomimetic by 202 stimulating the release of endogenous catecholamines. The endogenous catecholamine release 203 allows for hemodynamic stability; ketamine should be used with caution in those with a 204 prolonged shock state at risk for a catecholamine depleted state. 41 Hypotension after ketamine 205 administration may be seen in this population. 41,48 Appropriately dosed ketamine or etomidate 206 are the first line agents in patients with shock, with doses reduced to 25-50% of normal. 207

FIGREF2.text: is a frequent indication for airway intervention in the ED.4  An 215 exacerbation of obstructive lung disease leads to narrowing of the airways and bronchospasm 216 causing increased airway resistance, air trapping, hyperinflation, increased dead space, and 217 respiratory failure resulting in an elevated PaCO 2 and an acute respiratory acidosis.49  NIPPV 218 reduces mortality and the need for intubation and should be a first line therapy in those with 219 acute hypercapnic respiratory failure from an exacerbation of COPD. 50,51 Though less studied, 52 220 NIPPV can also be trialed in those with severe asthma exacerbations and evidence of respiratory 221 muscle fatigue. 49,53 In patients with COPD or asthma, BPAP settings of NIPPV are used to 222 maximize pressure support with an inspiratory positive airway pressure (IPAP) delivered with 223 each patient triggered breath to assist with ventilation. The inspiratory pressure can be increased 224 depending on the patient's response and tolerance, 49 usually not exceeding a peak inspiratory 225 pressure of ~20 cmH 2 O to avoid gastric insufflation. 15,54 When patients with obstructive lung 226 disease fail usual aggressive medical treatment and NIPPV, have a contraindication to NIPPV 227 (i.e. severely depressed mental status, inability to cooperate, etc.), or intolerance to NIPPV, 228 intubation and mechanical ventilation are needed. NIPPV may still be used to provide 229 preoxygenation and assistance with ventilation by "delayed sequence intubation" while preparing 230 for intubation as described by Weingart et al. 14 While the airway operator is maintaining the 231 mask seal and opening the airway, the NIPPV machine or a ventilator can be used to provide 232 breaths, with a safely set peak inspiratory pressure (i.e. <20-25 cmH 2 O) and a backup rate during233 induction. 15 Pearl: Trial and titrate NIPPV, along with aggressive medical management, in an attempt to 235 avoid intubation in those with obstructive lung disease. 236 237 Pitfall: Not anticipating the hemodynamic risk of a high intrathoracic pressure and decreased 238 venous return. 239 When choosing the induction agent in those with obstructive lung disease, clinicians should 240 consider comorbid conditions (i.e. heart failure, pulmonary hypertension, etc.) and the presenting 241 hemodynamic profile. A fluid bolus can be considered in this population due to the risk of 242 decreased venous return leading to hypotension, particularly in those at high risk for 243 hyperinflation or receiving NIPPV prior to intubation. 24,37 Ketamine may assist with 244 bronchodilation in those with bronchospasm from obstructive lung disease. 53,55,56 Ketamine also 245 allows for the maintenance of the respiratory drive if used in a delayed sequence strategy for 246 preoxygenation and ventilation with NIPPV. 14,15,25 247 Pearl: Ketamine may have bronchodilatory effects and is an ideal induction agent in 248 obstructive lung disease. 249 250 Pitfall: Inappropriate post intubation mechanical ventilation settings leading to breath 251stacking. 252Post-intubation mechanical ventilation places patients with obstructive lung disease at risk for air 253 trapping and dynamic hyperinflation, caused by incomplete exhalation before the next breath is 254given.28,49,53  This may lead to cardiovascular collapse by high intrathoracic pressure impairing 255 venous return to the right heart or barotrauma and pneumothorax. 24,49 Continued bronchodilator 256 therapy and aggressive medical management should continue while intubated. A recommended 257 ventilator strategy includes a respiratory rate (RR) of 8-14 with an inspiratory to expiratory (I:E) 258 ratio of 1:4 or greater, volume targeted mode with a tidal volume of 6-8 mL/kg PBW, and an 259 initial PEEP of 0-5 cm H 2 O, though some suggest a more complex strategy of a higher PEEP in 260 the case of COPD to match 80% of measured intrinsic PEEP (set PEEP + auto-PEEP) to assist 261 with patient triggering. 24,28,49,53 The respiratory rate can be adjusted to allow for full exhalation as 262 seen on the expiratory flow waveform on the ventilator inFigure 1. 28,49 Permissive hypercapnia 263

FIGREF3.text: 285 Pearl: Assess for air trapping on the ventilator. Air trapping from a high respiratory rate can 286 lead to hemodynamic collapse; a patient with a high spontaneous respiratory rate may require 287 deep sedation with or without neuromuscular blockade. The plateau pressure should be 288 assessed and maintained at < 30 cm H 2 O. 289 High airway resistance on pressure waveform. 291 Pulmonary Hypertension, Right Heart Failure, and Pulmonary Embolism 292 Pitfall: Failure to identify a patient with pulmonary hypertension or right heart failure. 293 Induction for intubation and positive pressure mechanical ventilation in those with pulmonary 294 hypertension (PH) and right ventricular (RV) dysfunction is risky, and improper management 295can lead to cardiovascular collapse. RV dysfunction is defined by abnormal RV filling or 296 contraction, while RV failure is defined by impaired RV function along with symptoms of heart 297 failure.57  In the ED this may be encountered as a chronic comorbidity with an acute insult (i.e. 298 sepsis, pneumonia, etc.) or as an acute process in the case of a pulmonary embolism (PE) or RV 299 infarction. Chronic elevations in pulmonary arterial pressure lead to chronic RV dysfunction or 300 failure and may result from underlying causes such as idiopathic pulmonary hypertension, 301 congenital heart disease, chronic lung disease, left-sided heart disease, chronic pulmonary 302 emboli, and others. 57,58 A suggestive physical examination (i.e. JVD, peripheral edema) or 303 reported history of pulmonary hypertension or RV failure along with review of the patient's 304 medications, medical record, prior echocardiogram, or a point of care ultrasound, may help 305 identify these patients so that adverse events can be mitigated prior to an intubation attempt and 306 post intubation mechanical ventilation challenges can be anticipated.58  A bedside ultrasound with 307 RV dilation and enlargement > ⅔ the size of the left ventricle in the apical view or flattening of 308 the interventricular septum causing a D shape is suggestive of pulmonary hypertension or RV 309 dysfunction. 12,58 310 Pearl: Identify those with RV failure and pulmonary hypertension using history, physical 311 examination, and prior echocardiogram or point of care ultrasound to anticipate their 312 complex physiology. 313 314 Pitfall: Not anticipating and preparing for the hemodynamic challenges of pulmonary 315 hypertension, right heart failure, and pulmonary embolism. 316 The pulmonary vascular system is usually a low resistance circuit with a thin walled RV acting 317 as the pump against a low afterload, with a mean right sided pressure much lower than the 318 systemic left-sided pressure. 58,59 The RV has limited capacity to adapt to an acute rise in 319 afterload, and acute elevations in pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) may worsen RV 320 dysfunction and precipitate RV failure and hemodynamic collapse. 12,57,58 Based on 321 interventricular dependence, RV dilation and pressure overload may lead to bulging of the 322 interventricular septum and compromise left ventricular function and cardiac output. 57-60 Acute 323 hypoxemia, hypercapnia, and acidosis lead to pulmonary vasoconstriction, and these precipitants 324 of an acute rise in PVR should be aggressively avoided in the failing RV. 57,58,61 The patient must 325 be preoxygenated, and during induction, hypercapnia and hypoxemia should be avoided. 49 Pearl: Avoid and manage precipitants of increased PVR including hypoxia, hypercapnia, and 327 acidosis. 328 329 Pitfall: Not treating hypotension, leading to an under perfused and ischemic right ventricle. 330 The RV is perfused during systole and diastole because of the typically low RV pressure and low 331 ventricular wall tension. 58,59 When the pulmonary artery (PA) pressure exceeds systemic blood 332 pressure, RV perfusion decreases, resulting in RV ischemia and a potentially deleterious cycle of 333 refractory RV failure, low cardiac output, hypotension, and hemodynamic collapse. 57,58 Pre-334 induction systemic hypotension or hypotension during an intubation attempt, particularly in 335 combination with an increase in PVR from hypoxemia or hypercapnia during an apneic period, 336 may precipitate this deadly cycle. 12,57 Norepinephrine can be used to maintain systemic blood 337 pressure in the patient with RV failure; phenylephrine should be avoided, as the pure alpha 1 338 effects will cause pulmonary vasoconstriction and an increase in PVR. 12,58 The induction agent 339 and dose should be carefully planned, favoring hemodynamically neutral agents such as 340 etomidate. 12 Those with RV failure and pulmonary hypertension are sensitive to changes in 341 preload. Volume overload may worsen RV dilation and ischemia, while hypovolemia will 342 decrease the cardiac output. 57 Unfortunately, the normal physical examination and ultrasound 343 findings of volume responsiveness are unreliable in this patient population. 12,57,58 If the history 344 suggests hypovolemia, a 250-500 mL fluid challenge can be administered, followed by a close 345 assessment for improvement. If the patient does not improve hemodynamically, further fluid 346 boluses are not recommended. 57,58 347 Pearl: Aggressively treat systemic hypotension with norepinephrine or cautious 250-500 mL 348 boluses only if the history suggests hypovolemia and use hemodynamically neutral induction 349 agents. The combination of a high PA pressure and low systemic blood pressure leads to RV 350 ischemia and risk of irreversible hemodynamic collapse. 351 352 Pitfall: Inappropriate mechanical ventilation settings leading to high intrathoracic pressure 353 post intubation 354 High-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) or NIPPV with low end expiratory pressures can be trialed in 355 an attempt to improve the respiratory failure and prevent invasive mechanical ventilation. These 356 non-invasive measures have the advantage of being easily removed should the positive pressure 357 cause hemodynamic compromise. 12,58 If preventative measures fail and the patient must be 358 intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation, post intubation ventilation strategies should 359 focus on normalizing PaCO 2 , pH, and oxygenation while maintaining low airway pressure. 58,61 360 The positive pressure decreases RV preload and increases PVR, potentially exacerbating RV 361 failure and hemodynamic compromise. A strategy of a low plateau pressure, low tidal volume 362 (i.e. 6 mL/kg PBW), and low PEEP (i.e. 5 cm H 2 O) is recommended. 58,61 363 Pearl: The mechanical ventilation strategy in those with RV failure and pulmonary 364 hypertension includes normalizing PaCO 2 , pH, and PaO 2 with a low-pressure strategy using 365 low PEEP (i.e. 5 cm H 2 O) and a low tidal volume. 366 367 Pitfall: Failure to treat a pulmonary embolism prior to induction and mechanical ventilation. 368 PE is a common, acute cause of RV pressure overload. 57 The normal RV has difficulty acutely 369 generating > 40 mm Hg of pressure in the case of PE, causing an acute pressure overload. 57 370 Systemic thrombolytic therapy is recommended in the hemodynamically unstable patient and is 371 suggested either systemically or catheter directed in select cases of the intermediate-high risk 372 category with low bleeding risk (i.e. poor gas exchange, RV dysfunction, myocardial injury, 373 etc.). 62 If indicated, systemic thrombolytics should be administered prior to intubation; 374 thrombolysis may prevent the need for intubation or at the very least decrease the risk of peri-375 intubation cardiac arrest. If the patient with an acute PE must be intubated, the same 376 considerations of low pressure as previously discussed apply. 377 Pearl: In the patient with acute RV failure from PE, treatment with thrombolysis in the 378 unstable patient prior to intubation is recommended. 379 380 Advanced treatment considerations in those with RV failure or pulmonary hypertension with 381 post-intubation refractory shock or hypoxemia include inhaled pulmonary vasodilators (i.e. 382 inhaled nitric oxide or epoprostenol) and mechanical support devices, including extracorporeal 383 membrane oxygenation. Such complex cases should be discussed with the pulmonary 384 hypertension specialist center and critical care physician. 58 385 Pearl: Consider transfer to a specialty center for the intubated patient with known RV failure 386 and/or pulmonary hypertension. 387 Severe Hypoxemia 388 Pitfall: Failure to adequately preoxygenate prior to intubation. 389 Hypoxemic respiratory failure from pneumonia and other causes is a common indication for 390 intubation in the emergency department and ICU. However, despite being a necessary and life-391 saving procedure in critically ill patients, intubation can have deleterious consequences, 392including worsening hypoxemia and cardiovascular collapse. Severe hypoxemia during 393 intubation is associated with adverse outcomes and is a risk factor for intubation-related cardiac arrest. 13,34 Not surprisingly, oxygen saturation at induction and hypoxemic respiratory failure as 395 the indication for intubation are among the strongest predictors of hypoxemia during 396 intubation. 63 Pre-intubation hypoxemia and lack of preoxygenation were also found to be major 397 predictors of intubation-related cardiac arrest in ICU patients undergoing emergent intubation. 13 398Pearl: Pre-intubation hypoxemia and lack of preoxygenation are predictors of adverse events. 399Pitfall: Not using NIPPV or appropriate positioning during preoxygenation. 400Preoxygenation and apneic oxygenation are the two primary interventions that should be 401 employed to improve pre-intubation pulse oximetry (SpO 2 ) and reduce the risk of desaturation, 402 with its subsequent complications, during intubation. Positioning during preoxygenation is 403 important in all patients, particularly in those that are obese, with a semi-upright or reverse 404Trendelenburg preferred. 64-66 Traditionally performed using a non-rebreather mask, several 405 studies have shown improved preoxygenation using NIPPV or HFNC in hypoxemic patients 406 requiring emergent intubation.67-69 Baillard et al. found that in severely hypoxemic patients 407

FIGREF4.text: Further supporting the use of 420 NIPPV for preoxygenation, a recent meta-analysis by Fong et al. of 7 randomized controlled 421 trials (959 patients) examining preoxygenation before intubation in adult patients with acute 422 hypoxemic respiratory failure found that preoxygenation with NIPPV resulted in significantly 423 less desaturation than preoxygenation with conventional oxygen therapy (non-rebreather mask or 424 bag mask valve) or HFNC. 69 Additionally, both NIPPV and HFNC resulted in a lower risk of 425 intubation-related complications than conventional oxygen therapy. 69 426 427

FIGREF5.text: 438 condition allows and utilize apneic oxygenation with HFNC. 439 440 Pitfall: Failure to use proper protective equipment in those with suspected respiratory 441 infections. 442

FIGREF6.text: 452 Pearl: Use airborne precautions when intubating and preoxygenating a patient with a highly 453 contagious illness such as COVID-19 454 455 CONCLUSIONS 456

TABREF1.text: ,10,34 There are many other contributors to post intubation 154 cardiovascular collapse including the severity of the underlying illness, age, hypoxemia, 155 sympatholytic action of the induction agents, and hemodynamic consequences of positive 156 pressure ventilation. 13,17,24,33,35 157 Pearl: PIH is common, should be avoided, and is associated with adverse outcomes. A shock 158 index of > 0.8-0.9 and preceding hypotension are predictors of hemodynamic compromise and 159 cardiac arrest that should be managed prior to induction. 160Pitfall: Failure to resuscitate prior to induction and intubation. 162Resuscitation and management of pre-intubation hypotension or elevated shock index >0.8-.0.9 163 is recommended to prevent adverse events(Table 2). Some call this approach "resuscitative sequenced intubation". 36 Volume resuscitation is recommended if hypovolemia is suspected. 165Hypotension from hypovolemia will be exacerbated by the decreased venous return with positive 166 pressure ventilation.24  Though beneficial for some, volume therapy should not be used167 indiscriminately. A recent study suggests a routine 500 mL fluid bolus prior to induction does 168 not prevent cardiovascular collapse. 37 In those with hypotension despite appropriate volume 169 resuscitation, an infusion of a balanced vasopressor such as norepinephrine with beta 1 adrenergic 170 activity to increase cardiac contractility and alpha 1 adrenergic activity to cause vasoconstriction 171 is recommended. 35,38 Epinephrine should be considered if there is bradycardia or if the patient is 172 unstable and in a pre-arrest state. 35 Phenylephrine is another option though less desirable in those 173 with a primary low output cardiogenic shock, as it is a pure alpha 1 vasoconstrictor and may result 174 in decreased cardiac output through an increase in afterload. 35,38,39 Furthermore, a significant rise 175 in afterload may be detrimental in those with myocardial ischemia causing cardiogenic 176 shock. 35,38,39 Bolus or push-dose vasopressors risk dosing errors and lack a proven benefit over 177 vasopressor infusions. 35,40 A vasopressor infusion should be initiated early, with adequate 178 volume resuscitation. If time allows, perform point of care ultrasound to evaluate volume status 179 and cardiac function. 12 The findings of the ultrasound may inform volume resuscitation or 180 vasopressor choice. Utilizing a pre-intubation checklist that incorporates management of 181 Pearl: Hypotension should be a component of a pre-intubation checklist, and pre-intubation 183 hypotension should be treated with volume in those who are volume depleted and/or a 184 vasopressor infusion such as norepinephrine. Perform a point of care ultrasound to assess 185 cardiac function and volume status. 186 Predictors of post intubation hypotension and cardiac arrest.

TABREF2.text: and tolerate a respiratory acidosis 268Deep sedation with or without paralysis may be needed to prevent patients from spontaneously 273 over-breathing the set rate, resulting in air trapping. 28,49 If neuromuscular blockade is used, 274 continuous deep sedation must be ensured to avoid awareness. If hypotension occurs, the patient 275 should be disconnected from the ventilator and external pressure applied on the chest to allow for 276 complete exhalation and re-starting at a lower respiratory rate when mechanical ventilation 277 resumes.49  The plateau pressure estimates end inspiratory alveolar pressure and reflects total 278 respiratory system compliance; plateau pressure should be assessed with an end inspiratory hold 279 and maintained at < 30 cm H 2 O. 28,49 A plateau pressure of > 30 cm H 2 0 in the setting of 280
